stream_context.summary: Kaze refactors Return to Yoshi’s Island’s code, optimises HUD rendering, and live-programs a new "ice Raven" enemy for the surreal ice-palace level, fixing crashes and Fast64 export issues along the way.

development_findings.summary: Refactored large parts of the RTYI codebase; game now boots and runs stably on real N64 hardware again after previous crashes.
development_findings.quote: I spent some time this week refactoring some of the RTUI code base… fixed a lot of crashes. The game is a lot more stable now.

development_findings.summary: Replaced the first overworld with a temporary debug overworld while development continues.
Implemented a new delegate system to render HUD elements on demand, saving roughly two microseconds in every level.
development_findings.quote: We save a few precious microseconds in every level – probably like two microseconds globally from that new system.

development_findings.summary: Plans to move frame buffers into separate memory segments; estimates a 2–3 % performance gain (~1 FPS) on N64.
development_findings.quote: I’m gonna try that sometime soon… probably like another two to three percent which, you know, that’s like a full FPS.

development_findings.summary: Initial design for Ravens (walk on geometry with ray-casts) proved complex; pivoted to Biobak’s idea: ice minions that pop out of ground/walls, walk a set path, then vanish – simpler and thematically stronger.
development_findings.quote: It’s cooler and easier to program.

development_findings.summary: Finished basic Raven behaviour: spawn offset in wall, rise, walk forward, turn after set distance, disappear; added hitbox, shadow, damage/ bounce interactions, and mash-to-break-free ice effect.
Fast64 export bug caused wrong behaviour values; fixed by adding parentheses in exported B-param expressions.
development_findings.quote: This is a Fast 64 bug… I forgot the plus.

development_findings.summary: Raven boss (Raphle the Raven) will return as a full boss fight with cosmic/moon elements; regular Ravens are smaller variants.
Next enemy planned: a snowman that rolls its head at Mario and regenerates segments like a Pokey.

Dan Salvato questioned the high-mobility dive-jump; Kaze is considering limiting mid-air angle change to stay closer to Mario 64’s ‘commitment’ philosophy and may release test builds with varying physics.
development_findings.quote: The thing is, this lets you change your angle in mid-air and nothing else in Mario 64 does… I’m thinking of limiting the use of the dive a little bit more.

development_findings.summary: Project status: working on 13th main course; Bowser stages, two side levels, and major overworld areas still pending; expects at least 2–3 more years plus bug-testing.
Maintains design rule: game is a pure platformer; avoids puzzle mechanics that slow pacing.
development_findings.quote: Puzzle stuff kind of seems against the basic design of this game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views large-scale N64 development as ‘scaling 50 Everests’ but remains motivated by hardware limitations and optimisation challenges.
context_findings.quote: Making this game is honestly like scaling 50 Everests.

context_findings.summary: He prioritises real-hardware performance, aiming for ~60 FPS on an actual N64.
He streams once a week, sometimes bonus sessions, balancing coding with personal life (mentions post-workout fatigue, spouse upstairs).
Not ‘friends’ with Nintendo; aware of legal grey area but continues project.
context_findings.quote: Me and Nintendo are not friends.

context_findings.summary: Openly engages community for design feedback (dive mechanics, enemy ideas) and integrates viewer-contributed code (e.g., Michi’s functions).

biobak.summary: Suggested redesigning Ravens to pop out of ice, walk briefly, then disappear – accepted and implemented.
biobak.quote: Pop out of ground, walk forwards, around the corner and then disappear… that would be so much easier.

zeina.summary: Provided Raven model and animations; collaborated on colour/material tweaks during stream.
Handled humorous ‘cum shake’ redemption and general stream support; demonstrates informal spouse-collaborator dynamic.

key_stories.title: Pivoting the Raven Enemy
key_stories.summary: Kaze initially planned complex geometry-walking Ravens. Biobak proposed making them ice creatures that simply emerge, walk, and vanish, fitting the theme and easing implementation.
key_stories.challenge: Ray-cast-based wall-walking logic was proving cumbersome.
key_stories.process: Discussed alternatives on stream; accepted Biobak’s suggestion; rewrote behaviour to spawn from walls/floor, saving time.
key_stories.outcome: Functional enemy completed during stream; can be placed widely without path-finding headaches.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s cooler and easier to program.

key_stories.title: Microsecond HUD Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: A new delegate system now renders HUD elements only when needed, shaving a few microseconds per level.
key_stories.challenge: Legacy HUD code consumed precious CPU on N64.
key_stories.process: Refactored RTYI codebase and implemented delegate calls.
key_stories.outcome: ~2 µs saved globally; contributes to 60 FPS goal.
key_stories.key_quote: We save a few precious microseconds in every level.

key_stories.title: The Dive-Jump Debate
key_stories.summary: External feedback questioned whether RTYI’s powerful dive compromises Mario 64 design principles.
key_stories.challenge: Dive allows mid-air course correction unlike original game.
key_stories.process: Kaze weighs Dan Salvato’s critique; contemplates limiting angle adjustment and releasing physics test builds.
key_stories.outcome: Mechanic under review; potential future pivot.
key_stories.key_quote: You jump, you’re kind of committed… maybe we should tone this down.

open_questions.context: Kaze confirmed Raphle the Raven will return with cosmic/moon mechanics but specifics are undecided.
questions: What unique mechanics will differentiate the boss from regular Ravens?
How will cosmic elements manifest on N64 hardware?
How will size and colour changes affect performance and narrative?

open_questions.context: Planned next enemy rolls its head and regenerates segments like Pokey; no technical plan shared.
questions: How will the rolling-head mechanic be handled on collision?
Will the enemy freeze or damage Mario?
Any special visual tricks on N64 to convey rolling snow?

open_questions.context: Kaze floated idea of storing frame buffers in separate memory segments for 2-3 % speed but hasn’t attempted it.
questions: What concrete memory layout changes are required?
Any risk of RDRAM bank conflicts or DMA overhead?
Is the gain worth potential compatibility issues?

open_questions.context: Multiple solutions proposed; no resolution yet.
questions: Which limitations (angle, velocity) are being prototyped?
Will demos be released for community play-testing?
How will level design adjust if dive is nerfed?

open_questions.context: Kaze estimates 2–3 years but many levels remain.
questions: What milestone schedule does the team follow?
Any contingency for legal or hardware manufacturing hurdles?
